prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CH and H2O
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe simultaneously CH and H2O lines. CH has hyperfine structure, splitting the hfs components into two doublets in two different spectral windows. Both CH and H2O are detected along the SW and NE lines of sight in Cycle 0 data. They will be used to derive the H2 column densities, check the time variations of the line profile compared with Cycle 0 data, study the absorption line profile thanks to their deep absorption, and set a limit on the variations of fundamental constants mu=proton-to-electron mass ratio and alpha=fine structure constant. This requests higher spectral resolution than other science goals. No other lines, besides CH and H2O, were detected in this tuning in Cycle 0, hence we set narrower spectral windows around these lines. We will also look for 13CH, within the band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Configuration: We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 1''. The two bright and compact lensed images of the blazar are separated by 1'', with well known relative positions from VLBI observations. Hence, as for Cycle 0 data, we will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The signal-to-noise ratio will be sufficient for the visibility fitting to separate both blazar images, even on a spectral channel basis.
Spectral setup: We request three basebands of 937.5 MHz wide centered on the lines of CH and H2O. Those will offer a velocity resolution of ~0.6 km/s, after spectral averaging by factor of 2 (which will decrease the data rate without compromising the velocity resolution). This is a factor two improvement, compared to Cycle 0 data, which will be used to tighten our constraint on a velocity shift between CH and H2O, related with variations of the mu and alpha constants. The last baseband is of 1.875 GHz, with a velocity resolution of 1.1 km/s, to cover the additional frequency range. It will be checked for any absorption lines, and for measuring the continuum flux ratio between NE and SW images and monitor its time and frequency variation (as done by Marti-Vidal et al. 2013).
Requested sensitivity: We estimate the flux density F(SW) and F(NE) of the two blazar images as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(NE)=1.7 Jy at 100 GHz, and a magnification ratio F(NE)/F(SW)=1.5. This gives F(SW)=0.5 Jy and F(NE)=0.8 at LO=290 GHz. We target a sensitivity of 3 sigma on optical depth of tau=0.01 toward the SW image, that is 1.8 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 3 km/s.
Pseudo time constraint: The absorption is variable over timescales of a few months. To optimize the science results, we would like to have observations done close in time (ie, within 3-4 months), to compare precisely the abundances of the different species. However, the variations are small enough (factor of two over a year has been seen at most), not to seriously compromise the science goals. At the moment, there is no way in the OT to set a common but flexible time window for different science goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CH+, 13CH+, CO7-6 and CI
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observe CH+ 1-0 as primary target.
Note that the CO 7-6, CI (2-1) and 13CH+ 1-0 lines are also in the band. The CO and CI lines will be easily detected toward the SW image, probably not toward the NE image. They will be used to constrain the excitation of the gas and set limits on variation of fundamental constants.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O+ and HCl
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observe several hyperfine transitions of the para-H2O+ ground state line, together with H35Cl and H37Cl 1-0 lines.
H2O+ abundance to be compared to that of OH+ for estimates of the cosmic ray hydrogen ionization and fraction of molecular hydrogen in the gas.
Will get the 35Cl/37Cl isotopic ratio.

Lines of 6LiH and CD+ also in the band but unlikely to be detected. Still upper limits on these two lines will be very interesting.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The z=0.89 molecular absorber toward the quasar PKS 1830-211 is the best known source for obtaining very detailed information on the physical and chemical state of the molecular gas in the disk of a galaxy with a look-back time of more than half the age of the Universe. In ALMA Cycle 0, we observed strong absorption lines of most common interstellar molecules, revealing the absorption along the two lines of sight with unprecedented detail. Now, we propose to focus on hydrides, the key molecules at the root of the interstellar gas-phase chemistry, and use them as diagnostics of the physico-chemical gas properties. We will investigate the nature of the absorbing gas, the cosmic ray ionization state of hydrogen, the local turbulence, the hydride chemistry, and the cosmological enrichment of the interstellar medium.
